transcript:
Therapist: You've made a great observation, Amir. This situation touches on some of the core beliefs we've been working on, such as "I'm not good enough or worthy of love." When you doubt your friend's enjoyment of the conversation, it may be influenced by this underlying belief. Let's explore this further using the downward arrow technique. If it were true that your friend didn't enjoy the conversation, what would that mean to you?

Patient: It would mean that I'm not interesting enough or that I'm not good at connecting with people.

Therapist: And if that were true, that you're not interesting enough or good at connecting with people, what would that mean about you?

Patient: It would mean that there's something fundamentally wrong with me, that I'm not worthy of having close relationships.

Therapist: Thank you for being open and sharing that, Amir. We've reached a core belief that we've identified before: "I'm not good enough or worthy of love." This belief can color how you interpret social interactions and relationships. When we hold a core belief like this, we tend to seek out evidence that confirms it and discount evidence that contradicts it. That's why it's so important to challenge these beliefs and develop more balanced and compassionate ways of thinking about ourselves.

Patient: I can see how this belief has been affecting me, but it's hard to let go of something that feels so true.

Therapist: You're right, Amir. Core beliefs are deeply ingrained and can feel very true, even when there's evidence to the contrary. Changing them is a process that takes time and practice. One way we can start to shift this belief is by actively looking for evidence that contradicts it. For example, you mentioned that your friend laughed and seemed engaged during your conversation and that you made plans to meet again. These are pieces of evidence that challenge the idea that you're not worthy of close relationships.

Patient: I guess that's true. It's just hard to focus on that evidence when the negative thoughts feel so loud.

Therapist: That's a common experience, Amir. Our negative thoughts can be very compelling, even when there's evidence against them. That's why we practice thought records and actively seek out contradictory evidence. Over time, it becomes easier to recognize and challenge those negative thoughts. Another helpful technique is to develop a more balanced and compassionate core belief to replace the negative one. What might be a more balanced belief about yourself and your worthiness of love and connection?

Patient: I suppose a more balanced belief would be that I am worthy of love and connection, even if I make mistakes or have flaws.

Therapist: That's a beautiful and balanced belief, Amir. It acknowledges that you're human and imperfect, like all of us, but that those imperfections don't negate your inherent worthiness of love and connection. As we continue our work together, we'll gather more evidence to support this new belief and help it take root. How do you feel about that?

Patient: It feels daunting, but also hopeful. I want to believe that about myself, even if it's hard right now.

Therapist: That's a great attitude, Amir. Change is often daunting, but it's also full of hope and possibility. We'll work together to make this new belief feel more true and natural over time. Remember, every piece of evidence we gather, every thought record we complete, is a step towards that new belief. Let's keep practicing and exploring together.
